Biosciences
Rationale
This module covers a broad range of topics in bioinformatics. However, students' feedback indicates that some topics should be covered in more depth allowing a better understanding of the subject. One of the module member of staff, teaching 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways', has retired. Therefore, we propose to lose the topic covered by the staff allowing the expansion of the 'Population Ecology' topic giving the students a more in-depth knowledge of modelling dynamic processes. As a consequence, assessment 5 will also be removed, as it currently covers the 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways' topic.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE721
Notes
This module is a requirement of several of the newly developed, successfully recruiting Masters’ programmes and has seen an increase in student numbers beyond the current maximum places of 55 students to ca. 80 students in 2022-23 and ca. 150 students in 2023-24. We expect a higher number in 2024-25. As the module is required for several programmes, we cannot cap the number easily, but at current staffing levels assessment load has become a challenge.

To cater for the more diverse educational background of students and to be able to manage these numbers without an increase in staff, we propose to:

1.Reduce the number of assessments from currently 3 to 2, decreasing students assessment workload. The first assessment will be released towards the middle of the module (40% of the total mark) and the second assessment will take place at the end of the semester (60% of the total mark), which will allow more time during the semester for teaching and students revising the material.

2.Increase contact time in computer workshops to allow for more interactive discussions between staff and students and among student groups. This will also allow more time to support students with more diverse previous educational backgrounds, such as some international students, some of whom say they struggle with the material based on feedback from student reps of some of the masters’ programmes. Student evaluations of the module suggest that the low number of responding students find the material slightly challenging.

3.Change the previous coursework assessment format for assessment 1 (previously worth 33%) to a 70 min online exam worth 40% of the module mark using a combination of multiple answer question (MAQ) and multiple choice question (MCQ) format. (40% of a standard exam lengths of 180 min for a 15 credit module amount to 72 min). The new assessment 2 (1500 word equivalence maximum, worth 60% of the module mark) will remain a data analysis coursework task, assessing the previous content of assessments 2 and 3, previously worth 33 and 34% of the module mark, respectively.

LIFE721 receives students from many Masters programmes and was designed to offer a broad overview of bioinformatics for all students. Bioinformatics is not always included in undergraduate-level education and when it is covered, the depth of coverage may vary. The number of students reporting weak prior exposure to bioinformatics has increased with the steep increase of international students in the module. Student numbers taking LIFE721 have increased 3-fold in the last two years due to the growth of our MSc programmes (from 50 to 150 students, with further growth expected).

Assessment 1 will test students’ knowledge in bioinformatics through data analysis of bioinformatics analysis results presented to them and other questions to probe their understanding of key principles. This will enhance the learning process by enabling students to address misconceptions and reinforce their understanding of module material. In assessment 2, it is expected that students will generate and interpret the results.

In addition, minor spelling and punctuation errors have been corrected throughout the module specifications.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment. Opportunity for feedback on assessment will be provided.
Educational Aims
To provide a broad overview of the use of informatics in the biological sciences, to give students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Bioinformatics is a key skill needed in many research settings. This module gives students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics such as sequence analysis, phylogenetics, and the modelling of proteins, and others. While lectures are provided on core topics, there is a strong emphasis on practical exercises to demonstrate the application of common tools and data sources in these contexts. Teaching is delivered in the form of a weekly lecture and workshops. Students will be given guided reading and online activities to support their learning. The module will be assessed by two coursework assessments. The assessments will allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory biology review: Students will be presented with a brief introduction of some of the aspects of biology required for the understanding of this module. Topics may include: transcription and translation, protein structures, protein evolution, single nucleotide polymorphism and allele frequencies.

Specific (bio)informatic analyses may include:
• Use of common databases important to biologists;
• BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool);
• Sequence alignment: the use different multiple sequence alignment methods and programs and analysis of sequences;
• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model protein structure and predict/interpret function from the results using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches.

In a typical week students will have 1 x 1 hr lecture followed one or two days later by 1 x 3 hr computer practical session. The remaining time is allocated to self-directed learning, which involves:
- preparing for the lecture and computer practical sessions using the material posted 48 hrs before in the virtual learning environment
- digesting the material afterwards using formative quizzes, recommended reading and external online resources
- revision before assessments
- taking on board and learning from feedback to formative and summative assessments

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills. Feedback on assessments will be provided.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. The module will be assessed via two assessments.

Notes applying to both assessments: Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas and discuss and defend these ideas. The assessments will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be data analysis in the format of a 70 min online test. Students will be required to interpret bioinformatics analysis results presented to them, along with other questions aimed at assessing their comprehension of key principles in the field.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis in the format of written assessment (1500 word equivalence) where students will be tasked with the production and analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Biosciences
Rationale
This module covers a broad range of topics in bioinformatics. However, students' feedback indicates that some topics should be covered in more depth allowing a better understanding of the subject. One of the module member of staff, teaching 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways', has retired. Therefore, we propose to lose the topic covered by the staff allowing the expansion of the 'Population Ecology' topic giving the students a more in-depth knowledge of modelling dynamic processes. As a consequence, assessment 5 will also be removed, as it currently covers the 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways' topic.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE721
Notes
This module is a requirement of several of the newly developed, successfully recruiting Masters’ programmes and has seen an increase in student numbers beyond the current maximum places of 55 students to ca. 80 students in 2022-23 and ca. 150 students in 2023-24. We expect a higher number in 2024-25. As the module is required for several programmes, we cannot cap the number easily, but at current staffing levels assessment load has become a challenge.

To cater for the more diverse educational background of students and to be able to manage these numbers without an increase in staff, we propose to:

1.Reduce the number of assessments from currently 3 to 2, decreasing students assessment workload. The first assessment will be released towards the middle of the module (40% of the total mark) and the second assessment will take place at the end of the semester (60% of the total mark), which will allow more time during the semester for teaching and students revising the material.

2.Increase contact time in computer workshops to allow for more interactive discussions between staff and students and among student groups. This will also allow more time to support students with more diverse previous educational backgrounds, such as some international students, some of whom say they struggle with the material based on feedback from student reps of some of the masters’ programmes. Student evaluations of the module suggest that the low number of responding students find the material slightly challenging.

3.Change the previous coursework assessment format for assessment 1 (previously worth 33%) to a 70 min online exam worth 40% of the module mark using a combination of multiple answer question (MAQ) and multiple choice question (MCQ) format. (40% of a standard exam lengths of 180 min for a 15 credit module amount to 72 min). The new assessment 2 (1500 word equivalence maximum, worth 60% of the module mark) will remain a data analysis coursework task, assessing the previous content of assessments 2 and 3, previously worth 33 and 34% of the module mark, respectively.

LIFE721 receives students from many Masters programmes and was designed to offer a broad overview of bioinformatics for all students. Bioinformatics is not always included in undergraduate-level education and when it is covered, the depth of coverage may vary. The number of students reporting weak prior exposure to bioinformatics has increased with the steep increase of international students in the module. Student numbers taking LIFE721 have increased 3-fold in the last two years due to the growth of our MSc programmes (from 50 to 150 students, with further growth expected).

Assessment 1 will test students’ knowledge in bioinformatics through data analysis of bioinformatics analysis results presented to them and other questions to probe their understanding of key principles. This will enhance the learning process by enabling students to address misconceptions and reinforce their understanding of module material. In assessment 2, it is expected that students will generate and interpret the results.

In addition, minor spelling and punctuation errors have been corrected throughout the module specifications.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment. Opportunity for feedback on assessment will be provided.
Educational Aims
To provide a broad overview of the use of informatics in the biological sciences, to give students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Bioinformatics is a key skill needed in many research settings. This module gives students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics such as sequence analysis, phylogenetics, and the modelling of proteins, and others. While lectures are provided on core topics, there is a strong emphasis on practical exercises to demonstrate the application of common tools and data sources in these contexts. Teaching is delivered in the form of a weekly lecture and workshops. Students will be given guided reading and online activities to support their learning. The module will be assessed by two coursework assessments. The assessments will allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory biology review: Students will be presented with a brief introduction of some of the aspects of biology required for the understanding of this module. Topics may include: transcription and translation, protein structures, protein evolution, single nucleotide polymorphism and allele frequencies.

Specific (bio)informatic analyses may include:
• Use of common databases important to biologists;
• BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool);
• Sequence alignment: the use different multiple sequence alignment methods and programs and analysis of sequences;
• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model protein structure and predict/interpret function from the results using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches.

In a typical week students will have 1 x 1 hr lecture followed one or two days later by 1 x 3 hr computer practical session. The remaining time is allocated to self-directed learning, which involves:
- preparing for the lecture and computer practical sessions using the material posted 48 hrs before in the virtual learning environment
- digesting the material afterwards using formative quizzes, recommended reading and external online resources
- revision before assessments
- taking on board and learning from feedback to formative and summative assessments

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills. Feedback on assessments will be provided.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. The module will be assessed via two assessments.

Notes applying to both assessments: Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas and discuss and defend these ideas. The assessments will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be data analysis in the format of a 70 min online test. Students will be required to interpret bioinformatics analysis results presented to them, along with other questions aimed at assessing their comprehension of key principles in the field.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis in the format of written assessment (1500 word equivalence) where students will be tasked with the production and analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Biosciences
Rationale
This module covers a broad range of topics in bioinformatics. However, students' feedback indicates that some topics should be covered in more depth allowing a better understanding of the subject. One of the module member of staff, teaching 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways', has retired. Therefore, we propose to lose the topic covered by the staff allowing the expansion of the 'Population Ecology' topic giving the students a more in-depth knowledge of modelling dynamic processes. As a consequence, assessment 5 will also be removed, as it currently covers the 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways' topic.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE721
Notes
This module is a requirement of several of the newly developed, successfully recruiting Masters’ programmes and has seen an increase in student numbers beyond the current maximum places of 55 students to ca. 80 students in 2022-23 and ca. 150 students in 2023-24. We expect a higher number in 2024-25. As the module is required for several programmes, we cannot cap the number easily, but at current staffing levels assessment load has become a challenge.

To cater for the more diverse educational background of students and to be able to manage these numbers without an increase in staff, we propose to:

1.Reduce the number of assessments from currently 3 to 2, decreasing students assessment workload. The first assessment will be released towards the middle of the module (40% of the total mark) and the second assessment will take place at the end of the semester (60% of the total mark), which will allow more time during the semester for teaching and students revising the material.

2.Increase contact time in computer workshops to allow for more interactive discussions between staff and students and among student groups. This will also allow more time to support students with more diverse previous educational backgrounds, such as some international students, some of whom say they struggle with the material based on feedback from student reps of some of the masters’ programmes. Student evaluations of the module suggest that the low number of responding students find the material slightly challenging.

3.Change the previous coursework assessment format for assessment 1 (previously worth 33%) to a 70 min online exam worth 40% of the module mark using a combination of multiple answer question (MAQ) and multiple choice question (MCQ) format. (40% of a standard exam lengths of 180 min for a 15 credit module amount to 72 min). The new assessment 2 (1500 word equivalence maximum, worth 60% of the module mark) will remain a data analysis coursework task, assessing the previous content of assessments 2 and 3, previously worth 33 and 34% of the module mark, respectively.

LIFE721 receives students from many Masters programmes and was designed to offer a broad overview of bioinformatics for all students. Bioinformatics is not always included in undergraduate-level education and when it is covered, the depth of coverage may vary. The number of students reporting weak prior exposure to bioinformatics has increased with the steep increase of international students in the module. Student numbers taking LIFE721 have increased 3-fold in the last two years due to the growth of our MSc programmes (from 50 to 150 students, with further growth expected).

Assessment 1 will test students’ knowledge in bioinformatics through data analysis of bioinformatics analysis results presented to them and other questions to probe their understanding of key principles. This will enhance the learning process by enabling students to address misconceptions and reinforce their understanding of module material. In assessment 2, it is expected that students will generate and interpret the results.

In addition, minor spelling and punctuation errors have been corrected throughout the module specifications.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment. Opportunity for feedback on assessment will be provided.
Educational Aims
To provide a broad overview of the use of informatics in the biological sciences, to give students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Bioinformatics is a key skill needed in many research settings. This module gives students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics such as sequence analysis, phylogenetics, and the modelling of proteins, and others. While lectures are provided on core topics, there is a strong emphasis on practical exercises to demonstrate the application of common tools and data sources in these contexts. Teaching is delivered in the form of a weekly lecture and workshops. Students will be given guided reading and online activities to support their learning. The module will be assessed by two coursework assessments. The assessments will allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory biology review: Students will be presented with a brief introduction of some of the aspects of biology required for the understanding of this module. Topics may include: transcription and translation, protein structures, protein evolution, single nucleotide polymorphism and allele frequencies.

Specific (bio)informatic analyses may include:
• Use of common databases important to biologists;
• BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool);
• Sequence alignment: the use different multiple sequence alignment methods and programs and analysis of sequences;
• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model protein structure and predict/interpret function from the results using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches.

In a typical week students will have 1 x 1 hr lecture followed one or two days later by 1 x 3 hr computer practical session. The remaining time is allocated to self-directed learning, which involves:
- preparing for the lecture and computer practical sessions using the material posted 48 hrs before in the virtual learning environment
- digesting the material afterwards using formative quizzes, recommended reading and external online resources
- revision before assessments
- taking on board and learning from feedback to formative and summative assessments

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills. Feedback on assessments will be provided.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. The module will be assessed via two assessments.

Notes applying to both assessments: Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas and discuss and defend these ideas. The assessments will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be data analysis in the format of a 70 min online test. Students will be required to interpret bioinformatics analysis results presented to them, along with other questions aimed at assessing their comprehension of key principles in the field.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis in the format of written assessment (1500 word equivalence) where students will be tasked with the production and analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model protein structure and predict/interpret function from the results using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches.

In a typical week students will have 1 x 1 hr lecture followed one or two days later by 1 x 3 hr computer practical session. The remaining time is allocated to self-directed learning, which involves:
- preparing for the lecture and computer practical sessions using the material posted 48 hrs before in the virtual learning environment
- digesting the material afterwards using formative quizzes, recommended reading and external online resources
- revision before assessments
- taking on board and learning from feedback to formative and summative assessments

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills. Feedback on assessments will be provided.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. The module will be assessed via two assessments.

Notes applying to both assessments: Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas and discuss and defend these ideas. The assessments will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be data analysis in the format of a 70 min online test. Students will be required to interpret bioinformatics analysis results presented to them, along with other questions aimed at assessing their comprehension of key principles in the field.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis in the format of written assessment (1500 word equivalence) where students will be tasked with the production and analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
